0_Atelectasis: A chest X-ray showing focal volume loss with mediastinal shift toward the affected side, consistent with atelectasis.
Frontal radiograph demonstrating linear opacification and elevation of the hemidiaphragm in lobar collapse.
Image featuring platelike opacities and crowding of pulmonary vessels indicative of atelectatic segments.
Radiograph showing displacement of interlobar fissures and ipsilateral hilar shift, supporting lobar atelectasis.
Image demonstrating compensatory hyperinflation of adjacent lobes with rib crowding over the collapsed region.
1_Cardiomegaly: Posterior–anterior chest radiograph with a cardiothoracic ratio exceeding 50%, suggestive of cardiomegaly.
X-ray depicting a double contour of the right heart border and overall enlarged cardiac silhouette.
Image demonstrating protrusion of the left cardiac border and prominent pulmonary vasculature in heart enlargement.
Chest X-ray with downward and lateral displacement of the cardiac apex, suggesting left ventricular enlargement.
Radiograph showing prominent right atrial border bulge with an enlarged cardiac silhouette consistent with cardiomegaly.
2_Effusion: Image illustrating meniscus-shaped opacity blunting the costophrenic angle, characteristic of pleural effusion.
Supine film showing homogeneous hemithorax opacity with dependent layering fluid sign.
Radiograph with lateral view revealing fluid-level crescent and obscured diaphragm edge.
Upright film demonstrating a small laminar effusion as subtle costophrenic angle blunting with mild basal haze.
Image suggesting a subpulmonic effusion with apparent diaphragmatic elevation and a laterally peaked hemidiaphragm.
3_Infiltration: Chest X-ray demonstrating patchy alveolar infiltrates with ill-defined margins in the lower lobes.
Radiograph with diffuse interstitial opacities and Kerley B lines indicating pulmonary infiltration.
Image showing confluent hazy opacities across multiple lung segments, consistent with multifocal infiltration.
Radiograph demonstrating peribronchial thickening and ill-defined perihilar haze consistent with inflammatory infiltration.
Image showing scattered ground-glass–like opacities with preserved lung volumes, compatible with early infiltration.
4_Mass: Image presenting a solitary round opacity larger than 3 cm with irregular margins suggestive of a mass.
Radiograph showing bilateral pulmonary masses, one with spiculated borders and surrounding haziness.
Chest X-ray featuring a well-defined lobulated lesion in the right upper lobe consistent with a mass.
Chest X-ray revealing a hilar mass with lobulated contour and associated bronchial narrowing.
Radiograph showing a cavitating pulmonary mass with an air–fluid level and irregular thick wall.
5_Nodule: Frontal X-ray with a solitary pulmonary nodule under 3 cm diameter and smooth margins.
Image showing multiple small round opacities, each less than 1 cm, scattered throughout both lungs.
Radiograph depicting a coin-like lesion in the right middle lung zone consistent with a nodule.
Image demonstrating a calcified, well-circumscribed granulomatous nodule with central or laminar calcification.
Radiograph showing a spiculated solitary pulmonary nodule with subtle pleural retraction.
6_Pneumonia: Chest radiograph with lobar consolidation and air bronchograms in the right lower lobe indicating pneumonia.
Image showing patchy bilateral opacities with onset of acute air-space disease typical of pneumonia.
X-ray demonstrating segmental consolidation with silhouette sign obscuring the right heart border.
Radiograph with a bronchopneumonia pattern showing peribronchial patchy opacities across multiple segments.
Image demonstrating improving pneumonia with decreasing consolidation and residual linear atelectatic streaks.
7_Pneumothorax: Frontal film with visible visceral pleural line and absence of vascular markings peripheral to it, indicating pneumothorax.
Image showing deep sulcus sign on supine radiograph consistent with anterior pneumothorax.
Chest X-ray featuring mediastinal shift away from the side of a large tension pneumothorax.
Upright film showing increased apical lucency with a sharp pleural line and partial lung collapse.
Lateral decubitus radiograph demonstrating free pleural air rising to the nondependent side, confirming pneumothorax.
8_Consolidation: Radiograph with homogeneous lobar consolidation and air bronchograms, typical of alveolar filling.
Chest X-ray showing dense segmental opacity obscuring vessels and airway walls.
Image depicting confluent consolidation in the right middle lobe with sharp lobar margins.
Radiograph demonstrating a lobar opacity with a silhouette sign against the adjacent diaphragm or heart border.
Image showing air bronchograms traversing dense alveolar opacity, supporting pulmonary consolidation.
9_Edema: X-ray demonstrating bilateral perihilar bat-wing pattern of edema with prominent interstitial markings.
Radiograph with bilateral Kerley B lines and peribronchial cuffing in pulmonary edema.
Image showing vascular redistribution to upper lobes and scattered alveolar infiltrates of edema.
Chest X-ray showing cardiomegaly with cephalization of pulmonary vessels and superimposed interstitial edema.
Radiograph demonstrating small bilateral pleural effusions accompanying findings of pulmonary edema.
10_Emphysema: Chest X-ray with hyperlucent lung fields, flattened diaphragms, and increased retrosternal airspace.
Radiograph showing barrel-chest configuration and bullae in upper lobes characteristic of emphysema.
Image depicting diminished vascular markings with diaphragmatic flattening in COPD emphysema.
Radiograph showing increased lung volumes with widened intercostal spaces and a vertically oriented, narrow cardiac silhouette.
Image demonstrating large bullae with curvilinear walls and paucity of peripheral vascular markings.
11_Fibrosis: X-ray with basal predominant reticular opacities and honeycombing typical of pulmonary fibrosis.
Radiograph showing fine linear interstitial markings and traction bronchiectasis in fibrotic lung.
Image depicting subpleural cystic changes and volume loss in chronic fibrotic disease.
Chest X-ray showing reduced lung volumes with reticulonodular opacities and architectural distortion consistent with fibrosis.
Radiograph demonstrating upper-lobe volume loss with hilar retraction and pleural-based fibrotic change.
12_PleuralThickening: Image illustrating irregular pleural contour with focal thickening along the lateral chest wall.
Radiograph showing calcified pleural plaques and apical pleural thickening in asbestos exposure.
Chest X-ray demonstrating diffuse pleural line thickening with adjacent subpleural opacities.
Image showing an apical pleural cap with a smooth pleural-based density consistent with chronic pleural thickening.
Radiograph demonstrating localized pleural thickening producing an obtuse costophrenic angle without a classic meniscus.
13_Hernia: Frontal X-ray showing air-fluid level in thoracic cavity consistent with hiatal hernia.
Image demonstrating retrocardiac opacity with mottled gastric bubbles above the diaphragm.
Chest radiograph with mediastinal widening and bowel gas pattern in left hemithorax indicating diaphragmatic hernia.
Radiograph showing a retrocardiac air-containing structure with visible rugal folds, supportive of a hiatal hernia.
Image demonstrating an anterior cardiophrenic-angle air–fluid level or gas-containing opacity compatible with a Morgagni-type diaphragmatic hernia.
